awd_titl_txt: Understanding and Prevention of Carbon Membrane Physical Aging
awd_abstract_narration:
Complex and energy-intensive technologies are required to separate the molecular components of gas in commercial, energy, or environmental applications. Replacing these technologies with membranes, a sort of molecular filter, could significantly simplify gas separations by reducing energy consumption and operating costs. Carbon membranes, obtained from the carbonization of polymer precursors at high temperatures, have demonstrated exceptional separation properties. However, the performance of carbon membranes declines over time because the material is subject to physical aging, wherein the pores in the membrane collapse. The goal of this research project is to understand the underlying mechanisms of physical aging in carbon membranes in order to implement appropriate methods of stabilization. Two distinct methods will be examined. The first involves increasing the rigidity of the pore structure in the carbon membrane. The second method embeds small metal pillars to prop open the pores of the carbon membrane preventing collapse. This project provides effective strategies to understand and minimize aging in carbon membranes, addressing a long-standing challenge. Robust carbon membranes can be immediately deployed in gas separation processes with minimal modifications, benefiting society through reduced environmental impact, lower energy consumption, and reduced energy production costs. Students at the high school, undergraduate, and graduate levels, including women and students from underrepresented groups, will be engaged in the research project, contributing to the advancement of science. This research is expected to have a positive impact on the education of students and the engineering community.

Gas separations such as carbon dioxide/methane, oxygen/nitrogen, or methane/nitrogen could significantly benefit from the implementation of aging-resistant membranes. Carbon membranes have the desired properties of high selectivity, high permeability, chemical resistance, and thermal stability to perform these separations under industrial conditions over other types of membrane materials. One major concern for carbon membranes is their tendency to age over time. Before the potential of carbon membranes for gas separations can be fully realized, a fundamental understanding of the aging process is required. The governing hypothesis of the project is that physical aging is driven by two factors that can be predicted by the intensity ratio of the disordered and graphitic bands from Raman spectroscopy. The first derives from non-covalent pi-pi interactions in large graphitic domains (intensity ratio <0.7), which provide a thermodynamically-driven force to restack, leading to pore collapse. The second originates from the carbonization of high free volume polymer precursors, which yields smaller graphitic domains (intensity ratio >0.7) with a higher density of sp3 carbons. The open structures of these carbons are not fully connected and collapse over time. The degree and mechanism of aging can be matched with the proposed methods of stabilization, that is crosslinking for highly graphitic carbons or pillaring for high free volume carbons. Thermal crosslinking of the polymer precursor will be utilized to rigidify the subsequent carbon membrane, thereby reducing physical aging. Pillaring will be accomplished by evenly dispersing metal-organic polyhedras (MOPs) into the polymer matrix. Upon pyrolysis, the MOPs produce metal nanoparticles between the graphitic layers of the carbon membranes, stabilizing the pore structure. Success of this project will eliminate a major barrier currently preventing the utilization of carbon membranes.

por.por_cntn:
Carbon molecular sieve membranes (CMSMs) represent one of the most promising materials for gas separations due to their unique porosity and surface chemistry, ease of fabrication, thermal and chemical stability, high flux, and superior selectivity, when compared to commonly used polymeric membranes and mixed matrix membranes (MMMs). A widely accepted model proposes that CMSMs separate gases primarily through adsorption and molecular sieving mechanisms that depend on the microstructure of the membrane. However, a major concern which must be addressed before CMSMs can become a viable option for industrial applications is their physical aging, which is the densification of membranes due to the collapse of the pores, accompanied by a drastic decrease in permeability.

 Our goal was to fabricate carbon molecular sieve membranes which resist pore collapse due to physical aging. We proposed that aging was driven by two factors. The first results from non-covalent forces, such as π-π interactions which are most significant for the case of large graphitic domains. The thermodynamic driving force to restack leads to pore collapse. The second results from carbonization of high free volume polymer precursors, which yields smaller graphitic domains with a higher density of sp3 carbons.  The open structures of these carbons are not fully connected and collapse with time. These two components manifest characteristic absorbances in their Raman spectra, with associated intensities of IG and ID, respectively. Our hypothesis was that we could predict, based on spectroscopic evidence, which carbons will have the greatest propensity to age and by which mechanism: non-covalent interactions  (ID/IG ratios <0.7) or loss of free volume  ID/IG ratios >0.7). The proposed research would then match the method of stabilization, crosslinking or pillaring, with the underlying cause of aging, restacking of large, or collapsing of small graphitic domains, respectively. To test this hypothesis, we prepared CMSMs from different polymer precursors and measured their performance with respect to flux, selectivity and resistance to physical aging.

The choice of pillaring or crosslinking is unambiguous at the extremes of ID/IG ratios but becomes less definitive as this ratio approaches the midpoint range. In theory, CMSMs with ID/IG ratios in this range could be stabilized against physical aging by utilizing either crosslinking, pillaring, or a combination.  

We explored a variety of pillaring agents and found a soluble metal-organic compound to be particularly useful as it could be uniformly dispersed in high amounts into the precursor polymer membrane and would provide nanoparticles upon pyrolysis to form the CMSM.  The size of these nanoparticles could be controlled using the pyrolysis temperature and time and tailored to the system under investigation.    We have explored the general effectiveness of pillaring with copper nanoparticles on aging prevention of CMSMs containing large pores that are derived from high several free-volume polymers. This approach resulted in retention of CO2/CH4 separation performance of up to ~100% for pillared PIM-1 derived CMSM compared to a 60% drop for non-pillared PIM-1 derived CMSM. PIM-1 is the highest free volume precursor we tested. A less dramatic but still significant improvement in stability upon pillaring for a CMSM derived from an intermediate free-volume precursor polymer suggests that pillaring alone is insufficient, and some combination and crosslinking will be needed. 

 The NSF funded research provided at least partial support for the work of 8 graduate students (2 PhD degrees granted, one still in progress), and 9 undergraduate students.  Many of the results were published in peer-reviewed journals, with several more manuscripts in preparation. The students had the opportunity to present their work at a variety of venues (national, regional and local meetings of the American Chemical Society, national meetings of The North American Membranes Society, and poster presentations at in-house research symposia).
